text: Spot on. Thanks so much to @KPaoletta.
author: TedGenoways

text: I haven't. But the relative absence of news may afford me some time this weekend.
author: TedGenoways

text: It’s amazing!
author: TedGenoways

text: If Mueller is anything like I am, he’s looking out the window, thinking: “What are deadlines anyway? Just arbitrary dates, right? I’m gonna scroll through Twitter for a few minutes and then maybe check out that new taco place.”
author: TedGenoways

text: Just great
author: TedGenoways

text: A remarkable day in Fremont, Nebraska, working with the amazing @FrancesSSellers in DC, on this piece. Many thanks to everyone at the @washingtonpost for giving this space.
author: TedGenoways

text: You should think about writing funny stuff for some kind of compensation. Not sure how that would work. Just spitballing.
author: TedGenoways

text: I needed that. This tweet made me laugh hard.
author: TedGenoways

text: “Say goodbye to writer” is an ominous sales pitch. Finish that thought, evil robo-accordion!
author: TedGenoways

text: Zombie Henry Wallace has my vote.
author: TedGenoways

text: Frances Ha
author: TedGenoways

text: Frances Ha
author: TedGenoways

text: I love everything about this entire exchange. Everyone should read everything by all three of these amazing writers.
author: TedGenoways

text: Oooh, that’s tantalizing.
author: TedGenoways

text: I said no such thing. I said there was no on-the-ground reporting. Desk summaries are not reporting. In response, the NYT sent a reporter. It’s a great story and front page today. Much more impact. Oh, and I’ve been asked to write a magazine story so thanks for driving interest.
author: TedGenoways

text: Oh, got it! Nunes comes from a family of dairy owners. And has been rather secretive about his dairy operations of late.
author: TedGenoways

text: Devin Nunes is suing @DevinCow—a twitter account sort of in the voice of one of his dairy cows—and the defunct Devin Nunes' Mom. The suit has generated a number of other accounts, such as @DevinNunesCock and @NunesDad.
author: TedGenoways

text: Interesting time to vilify the "East Coast of Nebraska."
author: TedGenoways

text: And let me just say: It's pretty odd for someone who bills himself as an adventure traveler to denigrate the importance of actually seeing a place and talking to the people who live there.
author: TedGenoways

text: Read the tweet. The bias is about where resources are allocated. Being on the scene is about the quality of the reporting. The story below is head and shoulders above the wire stories that NYT had been running. The reason is simple. Mitch Smith was there.
author: TedGenoways

text: Sigh... One last time... 1. I was talking about on-the-ground reporting, not general "coverage." (See the tweet) 2. I posted this three days ago. 3. "It's Probably Over for Us" is excellent, just what I was asking for—as I've tweeted.
author: TedGenoways

text: This op-ed by @gaarder impressed the hell out of me. It's great work. And the coverage by the @OWHnews in general has been excellent.
author: TedGenoways

text: I think there are things in this story (published tonight) that local press can't do. That's not a critique exactly, just a fact of life. That said... https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/18/us/nebraska-floods.html …
author: TedGenoways

text: The lede is visceral (b/c it's on the ground), the scope is broad (b/c it's the @nytimes). The first voice you hear is the voice of young farmer who spent the day gathering the bodies of dead calves. When I say there are some details you can't get from NYC, that's what I mean.
author: TedGenoways

text: People have asked why I wanted national coverage, reported from the ground. This is why. Read this story. https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/18/us/nebraska-floods.html …
author: TedGenoways

text: Very much appreciated—and many thanks to @MitchKSmith.
author: TedGenoways

text: For the record, I tweeted this w/o credit and apologize to @chrismachian. (My wife is frequently my photographer, so I know better.) I found it originally without credit & never expected this tweet to have this kind of life. Next time, I'll take an extra minute to find a credit.
author: TedGenoways

text: Yikes. Be careful out there.
author: TedGenoways

text: Devin Nunes is suing Devin Nunes' Cow.
author: TedGenoways

text: A footnote: National media can also do A LOT to highlight the essential work of local or regional media. @OWHnews has been exceptional in its coverage. There's a lot there to build on. If you ask me, this op-ed is a national story in itself. https://www.omaha.com/weather/record-snowfall-historic-bomb-cyclone-are-forces-behind-nebraska-floods/article_b7b6547d-d4d2-5363-ad64-1142f87a513a.html …
author: TedGenoways

text: National press asks some of the bigger questions: Will there be federal disaster relief from FEMA? Do the failures of dams, levees, and bridges reveal infrastructure issues? Will Offutt be rebuilt or relocated? But also, if this is climate change, what do we do? (2/2)
author: TedGenoways

text: IMO, it's different roles. The @FremontTribune is letting locals know that supply trucks are arriving w/ supplies. @JournalStarNews is focusing on Lincoln's water supply. @OWHnews has broader scope—covering Offutt AFB but also other communities in NE and IA. So... (1/2)
author: TedGenoways

text: The cocaine in Keith Hernandez's mustache, to be clear
author: TedGenoways

text: And cocaine
author: TedGenoways

text: By "this guy," do you mean Ross or Mr. Met?
author: TedGenoways

text: Come one, come all!
author: TedGenoways

text: Someone from New York saying they'll never forgive Nebraska for Donald Trump is.... *chef kiss*
author: TedGenoways

text: Read and get back to me.
author: TedGenoways

text: Maybe I just need to work harder.
author: TedGenoways

text: This kind of work has certainly made me popular here in my home state...
author: TedGenoways

text: Or maybe I should just focus on trying to explain where people from the middle of the country are coming from, with pieces like this...
author: TedGenoways

text: And like this...

author: TedGenoways

text: Would you suggest that I spend years reporting and writing investigative stories like this.....
author: TedGenoways

text: God knows I've got my complaints about Senator Sasse, but he has been present and communicating clearly with his constituents on this issue. His Twitter feed has been a source of quality information.
author: TedGenoways

text: There's no replacement for the work that AP does. Thanks to you all.
author: TedGenoways

text: Does it have a release date???
author: TedGenoways

text: Will do. And a million thanks, Erin.
author: TedGenoways

text: Beautiful, Ben. But some reason I always imagined that your grandpa built you a treadmill desk from the wooden wreckage of a river freighter and a bison-hide belt from a shirtwaist factory.
author: TedGenoways

text: From wire dispatches and press releases. Jesus, dude. Read the tweet. It says “reporting” and it says “west of Chicago,” i.e. on the ground. You’re either wrong and won’t admit it, or wrong and don’t know it.
author: TedGenoways

text: One last time: the subject at hand is on-the-ground reporting. This story was not reported from the ground. Also, on the subject of datelines, this story was published after my tweet. So, again, wrong, but please continue.
author: TedGenoways

text: Wrong on both counts. But have fun on Twitter.
author: TedGenoways

text: The problem is thinking of on-the-ground reporting as a toe touch. You can’t report—really report—from a distance. I know you know that. That’s why you send reporters to the scene to report every day.
author: TedGenoways

text: And reading her stories in @OWHnews and @OWHopinion.
author: TedGenoways

text: If you’re not following @ErinGraceOWH for updates on #NebraskaFlood, you should be.
author: TedGenoways

text: I specifically said that there were no stories reported from the scene. Read what I wrote.
author: TedGenoways

text: Seriously, you’re an investigative reporter for the @BostonGlobe. You must know how datelines work.
author: TedGenoways

text: Go, go @gaarder and @OWHopinion!
author: TedGenoways

text: Who do they have on the ground?
author: TedGenoways

text: I was born in Texas. Blood Meridian is on my list. I’m running to be the Judge, not some puny president.
author: TedGenoways

text: Be honest with me: Are you reporting your stories from a desk in Midtown Manhattan?
author: TedGenoways

text: We don’t have disagreements over assertions. Assertions are either true or false. If you’re challenging the assertion that there’s been no on-the-ground reporting by national outlets, then point to it. Not a desk report, not a wire dispatch. Reporting.
author: TedGenoways

text: The national media isn't covering Nebraska, because Ben Sasse cast a craven and hypocritical vote in the Senate? I don't think so.
author: TedGenoways

text: The tweet said: "I've been looking for a single story in the @nytimes or @washingtonpost REPORTED FROM WEST OF CHICAGO." New York City is east of Chicago, last I checked.
author: TedGenoways

text: FYI, this was written by Reuters, not the NYT, and the reporter is at a desk in NYC, not in Nebraska.
author: TedGenoways

text:
There are really only two kinds of Twitter...

1. Where you tweet something funny and people respond by explaining your own joke back to you

2. Where you tweet something serious and people respond by arguing against something you didn't say
author: TedGenoways

text: You know what drives me nuts? People who tweet stuff like this without apparently reading the tweet. My complaint was about the lack of on-the-ground reporting by journalists with a national perspective. I'd think you'd be in favor of such a thing.
author: TedGenoways

text: And the 2016 election was supposed to be the wake-up call for national media that they had misunderstood the middle of the country and needed to revamp their coverage. It's now 2019, the start of another cycle, and where is are the reporters?
author: TedGenoways

text: NYT currently has TWO openings for Social Media Strategists. I'm not talking about cash-strapped publications being raided by vulture capitalists. I'm talking about well-funded publications that claim a national scope but don't commit resources for actual reporting.
author: TedGenoways

text: My wife works for NET, which produces Nebraska Public Radio and Nebraska Public Television. It's one of the oldest public media affiliates in the country. But thanks for making my point about the dangers of uniformed coverage.   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nebraska_Educational_Telecommunications …
author: TedGenoways

text: I think you've got me confused with someone else.
author: TedGenoways

text: I said: "I've been looking for a single story in the @nytimes or @washingtonpost reported from west of Chicago." Again, reported from west of Chicago. Not a desk rewrite of news releases and wire dispatches. Actual reporting.
author: TedGenoways

text: I really couldn't say why @KCStar hasn't reported on it.
author: TedGenoways

text: FYI, you’re downstream.
author: TedGenoways

text: VIA AP—which is to say, not reported from the ground, which is to say: just exactly what I said.
author: TedGenoways

text: No one said it was a plot. It’s about priorities. This started on Wednesday and the national media hasn’t arrived yet. Summarizing new releases isn’t reporting. Meanwhile, this is the main highway between Nebraska’s largest city and South Dakota’s largest city.
author: TedGenoways

text: Thanks for asking. For starters, my wife produced this segment for Nebraska Public Media in association with @FERNnews and @NPR. You should check out the whole podcast. It’s really good. And remind me: What did YOU do?
author: TedGenoways

text: Okay, I guess it was just a dumb, dumb tweet.
author: TedGenoways

text:
Easy rule: When you start any sentence with “I’m sorry but I have no sympathy for XX people who...”

1. You’re not sorry
2. You’re about to reveal your prejudice
author: TedGenoways

text:
Reporting is my business. Distance matters. Who do you think provides the information that big outlets poach? It’s either local or official—and both need to be checked out.

As for the intelligence of the caveat, some free advice: resorting to name-calling reveals you.
author: TedGenoways

text: I said "reporting from west of Chicago." We're talking about on-the-ground reporting. Saying that they've run stories without dispatching reporters is precisely my point.
author: TedGenoways

text: "Moving the goal posts," by definition, is changing the standard after a discussion has already begun. I set the standard in the original tweet. You didn't read it. It seems a bit of a pattern.
author: TedGenoways

text: Dude, the original tweet said "reported from west of Chicago." If you don't read before you tweet, that's not on me.
author: TedGenoways

text: This is the Washington Post desk report. Verbatim.
author: TedGenoways

text: That’s North Bend.
author: TedGenoways

text: Interesting take.
author: TedGenoways

text: Exactly—and all those barns
author: TedGenoways

text: When the water has receded and people have had a chance to rebuild, can we revisit the wisdom of building countless hog and chicken barns in the floodplain upstream from the wells where Omaha and Lincoln draw their drinking water?
author: TedGenoways

text:
I've written for both the NYT and WaPo multiple times in recent years. Maybe Google it.

So here's some info for you: "covering" something and "reporting" something are not the same. Rounding up tweets from DC is NOT reporting.
author: TedGenoways

text: It reminds me of the Dylan Thomas comment about a Welsh friend who had tried so hard to affect a London accent "that he sounds like a man speaking with the Elgin marbles in his mouth."
author: TedGenoways

text: Thank you. I'm getting tired of doing that.
author: TedGenoways

text:
1. This story was published after my post
2. It still wasn't reported from the scene

Reporting from a desk in DC has its place. I'm asking for on-the-ground reporting, i.e. "west of Chicago," per original post.
author: TedGenoways

text: And I'm glad you mentioned goal posts... A friend posted this on Facebook with the note: "Where I played football in high school."
author: TedGenoways

text: Thank you so much for that. And that's what I'm talking about: we only know what's happening in Fremont, because you're there—& the reporters from the @FremontTribune. National media can do more, IMO, to support that reporting. Highlight it, credit it, follow up on it. Stay safe!
author: TedGenoways

text: Nothing but respect for the reporters doing the work. Are you still in Fremont?
author: TedGenoways

text: I said right from the beginning "reported from west of Chicago." If you're not on the scene, if you're not asking questions, if you're not testing govt releases with your own eyes, then you're not reporting; you're blogging. It's what newspapers used to deride as "hack work."
author: TedGenoways

text: If well-financed national media doesn't contribute on-the-ground reporting, those big questions aren't asked. Real problems aren't solved. People feel ignored, abandoned. It's media's role to report. And if you're a national publication, you're supposed to cover the whole nation.
author: TedGenoways

text: Once more from the top... Yes, local reporting is vital—but it's also harshly underfunded & muzzled. Every major newspaper in Nebraska, for example, is owned and/or managed by one out-of-state company now. Don't expect probing questions about climate change, infrastructure, &c.
author: TedGenoways

text: This is a weather blog rounding up tweets and press releases from government agencies. Work like this from @islivingston serves a purpose, but this piece doesn't contain any original reporting, much less on-the-ground reporting.
author: TedGenoways

text:
https://www.kearneyhub.com 

https://www.theindependent.com
author: TedGenoways

text: AGREED.
author: TedGenoways

text: There’s a big difference between recycling wire reports built from local coverage and dispatching your own reporters. Not just in the quality and scope of the reporting but, more importantly, in the pressure it brings on policy makers.
author: TedGenoways

text: National coverage would increase relief funding. It might also focus attention on infrastructure failures (levees, dams, bridges) that have exponentially increased the damage.
author: TedGenoways

text: Try again.
author: TedGenoways

text: Yes, thank you. My point is: These outlets have the resources to dispatch reporters or hire stringers or freelancers. Local press serves an important role, but we need national media to be asking different questions and offering broader perspective.
author: TedGenoways

text: So I guess today’s lesson for me is: People have absolutely no ability to distinguish on-the-ground reporting from desk rewrites of dispatches coming over the wire.
author: TedGenoways

text: I know your house must be flooding, @BenSasse. Thanks for taking the time to survey the damage elsewhere and delivering the news to the president. Nebraska is counting on you.
author: TedGenoways

text: I'd add the @FremontTribune.
author: TedGenoways

text: Literally, reported from a desk in Chicago. If you read my original tweet, I said: nothing west of Chicago. Chicago is not west of Chicago.
author: TedGenoways

text: The situation in Fremont is really unreal.
author: TedGenoways

text: Wire stories and feeds from affiliates. Recycling local coverage doesn't make it national coverage. And without proper resources to cover what's happening, insufficient federal resources are committed to relief.
author: TedGenoways

text: What would the coverage be if this flooding were spanning from DC to Boston? Or across a similar swath of California?
author: TedGenoways

text: Here's a map, courtesy of the @StarTribune, showing flood-stricken areas: covering half or more of Nebraska, Iowa, and Wisconsin, as well as significant parts of Michigan. Interstates and highways are closed. Cities like Omaha, Des Moines, and Milwaukee are experiencing flooding.
author: TedGenoways

text: People often ask what I mean when I talk about coastal media bias, so here's an example: Much of the Great Plains is underwater and has been for days. I've been looking for a single story in the @nytimes or @washingtonpost reported from west of Chicago. Nothing. This is Nebraska.
author: TedGenoways

text: If you're mad about Maya Angelou, you may want to sit down before I tell you about Ezra Pound and T.S. Eliot.
author: TedGenoways

text: I met Maya Angelou when I was an undergraduate. I called her "Dr. Angelou." I called all of my professors "Dr./Ms./Mr." It wasn't about being deferential to them; it was about being reverential to the knowledge they possessed, the knowledge they earned and I wanted.
author: TedGenoways
